title: Is there a new AP CDR item in the making or even considering ?
body: I'm tired of needing to run like 20%/lvl cdr in runes for Vlad and still having to buy the cdr boots to reach max cdr with AP items. I lose resistances and AP and I still need to lose the mpen from the boots, feels so dumb. Even with mana mages where I can buy the athenes or morellos, if you run cdr/lvl glyphs which makes you squishy as shit, which would be ok because it's a trade-off,  you still don't get the max cdr. Meanwhile, on AD version you can get 40% cdr without even wanting to get it.

replies.body: I don't believe there's specifically an AP/CDR item in the works at the moment, but we are aware of the concern and thinking about the issue.

{{item:3031}} 80-65

Depends, caster marksmen like Lucian do have a greater damage increase with ER due to how his passive works; Graves is probably the same due to being able to reload more often due to dashes.

That's not true. Not all ADCs are the same anymore. For auto-centric ADCs like Jinx and Cait, sure ER won't be as good for DPS. But for ability casting ADCs like Ez, Lucian, or Corki, ER is much better than IE in terms of DPS increases. CDR and mana regen aren't just "utility" if you have damage-based spells.

Because the damage-output of AP Champs is directly tied to how fast a champion can throw out their spells. ADCS rely more on AAs to do consistent damage, and CDR is less relevant on them compared to offensive stats like crit/AD/arpen/LS.

There was never anything wrong with the *stats* of DFG, it was the old active that was broken and needed to be gotten rid of.  I see no reason why a reworked DFG with either a different active (not a nuke or damage amp), or a unique passive (because completed items should be something more than a pure ball of stats) couldn't coexist with Ludens and the rest of the current AP item lineup.

self-responded to add: someone else downthread pointed out that CDR is especially valuable to utility mages, who would also benefit more from something that is not a damage amp (putting a damage amp on a CDR item also confuses the "more spells per minute or more punch per spell" decision axis; people who want to blow you up in one rotation shouldn't value CDR that highly, but DFG was a big deal for them because of how much it added to that one rotation).

I think the movement speed proccing version of Lost Chapter (I forget the name and the BMB items aren't in the forum codes anymore) could be reasonable as a new real item (perhaps substituting {{item:3108}} {{item:3114}} directly in the recipe because it wouldn't make much sense to also add Lost Chapter itself if there is only one upgrade path).  Maybe the turret-wrecking one too, but only if turrets continue to be buffed until they are at least somewhat tough; we don't need more ways to 100-0 the current paper turrets in the time it takes to back and shop once.

But those won't help people who don't want to build {{item:3165}} because they're manaless, since they were basically "morello with a different passive" and had mana stats too.  They would make {{item:3165}} more situational rather than "build stats I want anyway and get grievous wounds for free", though.

Alternatively or in addition, they could simply trade some of Rylai's current stats for 10% CDR (perhaps substituting {{item:3067}} or {{item:3108}} in the recipe depending on which stats they would cut to make room in the power budget).  Casting more spells and adding a utility effect to each spell you land fit together reasonably well and Rylai's stats are universally non-useless for anyone with any AP ratios at all.  (Health may or may not be high priority but it doesn't feel as bad as building mana on {{champion:68}} {{champion:8}} {{champion:154}} ).

No, therefore mages should have a *harder* time building CDR, because each point of it is more valuable to them.  It should be a major selling point of an item and not something you get as a freebie.

They should have a real choice to make between casting more spells (CDR), or casting harder hitting spells (deathcap, ludens).  Currently the "more spells" niche is taken mostly by items that give *both* mana stats *and* CDR, because you can't use the CDR to its full effect without mana stats... unless you're manaless.  But never running out of mana is a big advantage already, do manaless champions really need separate items just for them?
given that most AP item simple got a price increase for reason, why not add 10% CDR to some to justify the price increase?

Riot just took a fat shit on mages. Doubt they'll be giving them anything nice anytime soon. If I remember correctly, their reasoning was something like this: "Since mages rely on spells and cooldowns for the entirety of their impact, it'd be broken and it'd limit build paths if we introduced an easy 40/45% CDR build path. Since ADC's rely on crit and CDR doesn't really make or break them, it's perfectly ok to give them 30% from one item without detracting from the rest of their build." ... Which is complete bullshit.

ALL of a mage's power resides in their spells. They NEED their spells to be at all useful. Having a viable 40% build doesn't necessarily mean having a 40% build that gives oodles of AP and magic penetration, as Riot seems to think---maybe it's because their 40% ADC build comes bundled with loads of AD and crit; indeed, the ADC 40% _scales_ off crit. It's rather disingenuous to provide a free 30-40% CDR to champions who massively benefit from it (ie Lucian, MF, Quinn, Graves), then turn around and say that mages would benefit too much from an easy 40% build.

Mages may need their spells to be useful, but their cooldowns are there specifically to give the opponent some breathing room. Mage players seem to want to be able to throw all of their abilities out constantly in a never ending rotation, but if that's the case Riot would have to balance their damage and mana costs around being spammed, and that limits the usefulness of players who want to off-build with max AP or some kind of tanky utility with Liandry's/Rylai's.

Because ADCs don't have 1000+ range on their auto attacks (except Cait, but that's quite new).

Mages are also tanker than carries, so they get punished less for being caught out. Their abilities deal damage in an area and have crowd control. Comparing them to the flat damage that an auto deals is pointless.

Mages have to be tankier because they don't have real access to lifesteal or sustain (with some exceptions like Vlad and Swain-- WOTA just isn't good on a majority of mages because of the AOE/DoT penalties). ADCs all have access to sustain (especially now, with the Warlord's mastery, it doesn't even take an item slot!)

Am I'm the only one not striving for Max CDR on my builds? I just find it way better to hit harder, rather than more frequently. Only and hand full of spell slingers really do better with max CDR, compared to Higher AP. (And not Every AP is a spell slinger.)

It depends what you play in general.

If you play full damage/burst mages like LeBlanc or Annie, you can very easly rush damage and kill as many people as you can to snowball.

If you play utility mages instead , going full damage/AP isn't the best way to utilize their utility.

Also , the full CDR build didn't trade any AP , just the Sorcerer's Shoes , a magic penetration item. The old offensive masteries gave you 5% CDR (this mastery has been removed) , the old Lucidity Boots gave you 15% CDR ( now it gives you only 10% ). With Athene's/Morello's , you could achieve the 40% CDR cap (no runes or any other item). Today , with this build you will still need 10% CDR to achieve the cap , despite the fact that you actually trade damage ( Magic Penetration ) for it.

It isn't the problem that EVERYONE wants to build full CDR , it is the problem that a build path has been removed/nerfed, and there are less choices to make as a mage in terms of items. 

Some people prefer to offer utility instead of damage/kills for their team. CDR was and still is the best stat for that.

Actually the full cdr build didn't lose any pen or ap.  You just would run cdr per lvl glyphs instead of mr glyphs.  So you'd do equal damage just be squishier in lane, which was a fair trade-off in my book.

My only problem with the CDR per level glyphs is that you don't reach the cap as soon as the Lucidity Boots build. 

In my opinion , when I need CDR on a mage , I need it at least in the mid-game , when teamfights start. When you play a champion that isn't focused on dealing damage , like Lulu , your only focus is to offer as much utility as you can.

Also , trading the MR glyphs for CDR/level is a significant trade for me. You practically trade your early game safety for a bit more utility in the late game. Most of the times you will see that the early stages of the game are the most deciding factors of a match. Still , I think you can get away with some long range champions ( Lux comes to my mind ).

So yeah , I agree that your build path works , with the only problem that the results come later (than you want) for some utility champions.

Vel'Koz needs CDR to proc his passive more.
Veigar needs CDR to Q-stack.
